column4: hello, can someone help me with resizing a partition... For some reason it cant resize it using Part.Magic and Gparted.  I think there are errors on the drive
What filesystem?
fat32
It was working fine for me the other day, till i had to resize the partition to make it bigger so i can put more files onto it. the partition was at the end of the drive
i simply resized it so it was the whole drive and now i cant resize it to make it smaller nor can i access the drive
There's probably some FS corruption then... you're really going to need to run a recovery tool on it first.
where can i get a recovery tool...? will i lose the files on there now?
No idea... someone who knows fat32 recovery would be better able to answer that, I haven't had to recover any files off a drive like that for a loooong time...
What did you use to expand the drive in the first place?
thanks for the help... this sucks i just got this damn drive for xmas and i already screwed it up lol
It's a software thing, so not as serious (at least by the sounds of it).
partition magic... the damn thing froze or something when resizing it too
Argh, that's no good... did it reboot and resize, or just resize while Windows was running?
when i partitioned my internal drive.. it rebooted. but this is an external drive. i was expecting it to reboot but it didnt
It only needs to reboot when the drive is locked (ie: you booted off of it)... it doesn't need to reboot for external drives or non-system drives.
Something like "/dev/sda1 not found in /etc/fstab"?
Are you sure you have the mount parameters right?
no it said "Warning: device /dev/sda5 is already handled by /etc/fstab, supplied label is ignored
You need to be root... "sudo mount /media/sda"
now its saying mount: unknown filesystem type 'fat32' now thats odd
wont he have to make a new partition as fat32  in order to listen to his mp3s on linux
You can still read ntfs drives, you just can't write them.  And the default permissions are finicky.
physical errors or filesystem corruption?
If you're unsure, back it up somewhere else with dd, and go ahead and fix it (DON'T check/repair a filesystem that is mounted).
